abstract.p: This article describes the practical application of a vibration control technique, developed by the authors and known as the receptance method, to the AgustaWestland W30 helicopter airframe in the vibration test house at Yeovil. The experimental work was carried out over a total of 5 days in two visits to the Yeovil site during February and March 2011. In the experiments, existing electro-hydraulic actuators were used; they were built into the airframe structure and originally designed for vibration suppression by the methodology known as active control of structural response developed at the AgustaWestland Helicopters site in Yeovil. Accelerometers were placed at a large number of points around the airframe and an initial open-loop modal test was carried out. In a subsequent test, at higher actuator input voltage, considerable non-linearity was discovered, to the extent that the ordering of certain modes had changed. The vibration modes were, in general, heavily damped. Control was implemented using measured frequency response functions obtained at the higher input level. After acquiring the necessary measurements, simulations were carried out and the controller was implemented using MATLAB/Simulink and dSPACE. The closed-loop poles were mostly assigned with small real parts so that the system would be lightly damped and sharp peaks would be clearly apparent in the measured closed-loop frequency response functions. Locations of the open- and closed-loop poles in the complex s-plane were obtained to verify that the required assignment of poles had taken place.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: This article describes the active vibration control of an AgustaWestland W30 helicopter airframe based on vibration test measurements in the form of input–output frequency response function (FRF) measurements. The theoretical basis of the receptance method has been presented in a series of papers [1–4] including studies carried out on experimental rigs in the laboratory. In this article, the first application of the method to an industrial-sized structure is described.

The general procedure involves the construction of a receptance matrix (or FRF matrix between any inputand output measurements) for multiple actuators and sensors, each term being a function of frequency ‘ω’. Rational fraction polynomials are fitted to the measurements and in this way a matrix of receptance transfer functions are formed, each being a function of the Laplacian complex frequency ‘s’. This matrix is the mathematical model; in theory, it is the inverse of the dynamics stiffness, H(s)=(Ms2+Cs+K)-1. However, there is no need to know or to evaluate the matrices, M, C, and K, which generally contain errors and approximations not present in the measured receptances. Another important advantage is apparent when the more general transfer function matrix is considered, typically output voltage from sensors/input voltage to actuators. In this case, there is no need to model the dynamics of the actuators and sensors, which are then included in the measurement.

The theoretical basis is provided from the linear algebra by the Sherman–Morrison formula [5], which enables the inverse of a modified matrix to be determined from (a) the original inverse matrix and(b) a known modification. In this case, the modification is provided by the controller and the original inverse matrix is the measured H(s). It has been demonstrated how natural frequencies, damping values, and anti-resonances may be assigned to a structure by this method [1, 2]. Techniques for the assignment of poles (natural frequencies and damping) that are robust to measurement noise on the data were explained by Ghandchi Tehrani et al. [4]. Another aspect of the work is the so-called partial pole placement, when certain natural frequencies and damping values are assigned while others are chosen to remain unchanged by the control action. This is achieved by selecting the excitation so that the unchanged poles are uncontrollable [3]. It requires a particular arrangement of the sensors to excite only a subset of chosen modes, a facility that was not available to this study, as will be explained presently when discussing the availability of actuators.

In this article, a study is described that demonstrates the application of the receptance method to the vibration control of large industrial-scale structures. It is shown that not only can damping be assigned but also the natural frequencies, for example, for the avoidance of resonance in the case of harmonic excitation, such as the blade-passing speed and its harmonics in a helicopter. What is considered to be of interest to researchers is the scale and complexity of the test structure and the fact that the methodology is successful is assigning the required dynamic behaviour.

sec.title: 2 EXPERIMENTAL SET-UP
sec.p:
The W30 airframe, supported on its wheels with inflated tyres, is shown in Fig. 1 at the time the tests described in this article were conducted. The engines and main gearbox are mounted on a steel framework which is itself supported by four elastomeric mounts on the roof of the cabin. An electro-hydraulic actuator [6, 7] forms an integral part of the support system andimparts an internal force between the raft and the fuselage in parallel with each of the four elastomeric mounts. This configuration, shown in Fig. 2(a) and (b), forms part of the original AgustaWestland active control of structural response (ACSR) structural vibration control system, the purpose being to isolate the fuselage from blade-induced vibration at harmonics of the blade passing speed. Operation of the system, based on the use of a reference signal to detect the harmonics concerned, was based on adjusting the magnitude and phase of the actuator forces so that a quadratic cost function was minimized. This procedure, of the feed-forward type, is described by Fuller et al. [8] and also by Pearson and Goodall [9]. Implementation of the ACSR system is described by Staple [6] and Staple and Wells [7]. Fig. 1
W30 airframe during testing: (a) overview of the test arrangement and (b) close-up of the gearbox, raft, and actuators Fig. 2
Raft and electro-hydraulic actuators: (a) raft and its position on the aircraft and (b) electro-hydraulic actuator with parallel elastomeric support

In this exercise, a feedback system was applied using the receptance method. The work was carried out over a period of 5 days during two visits to the AgustaWestland site at Yeovil in February and March 2011. The main gearbox was present but the engines had been removed. Consequently, there was insufficient mass over the two rear actuators for reacting the fuselage force. It was decided that these two actuators would be pressurized and used passively. Thus, only the two front actuators were available for active vibration control.

During the first visit, a preliminary open-loop modal test was carried out using 20 triaxial accelerometers (60 channels) with low-level excitation independently applied to the two electro-hydraulic actuators – zero-mean random input to the amplifier in the range ± 0.1 V. The frequency range was 0–50 Hz and the sampling frequency 100 Hz at a resolution of 512 spectral lines with a Hanning window. The results of this test are summarized in Fig. 3. The two ‘active’ electro-hydraulic actuators were located at nodes 19 and 20 with loads applied to the roof of the fuselage and to the raft in equal and opposite ± z-directions. Fig. 3
Open-loop modal test results: (a) vertical tail bending 12.6 Hz, 5.31% damping, (b)horizontal tail bending 14.6 Hz, 2.78% damping, (c) airframe vertical bending 17.5 Hz, 5.95% damping, and (d) airframe horizontal bending and torsion 25.4 Hz, 5.93% damping

On the second visit, preliminary tests were carried out to ensure that the structure had not changed significantly. In addition, a vibration test at a higher excitation level (random with zero mean and range ± 2 V) was carried out. A comparison of two FRFs at the two different excitation levels is given in Fig. 4 where significant differences can be observed. The signal at low amplitude appears to be much noisier than the higher amplitude signal, possibly due to non-smooth non-linearity of the actuator, such as stick-slip behaviour, at small displacements. There are clear discrepancies in amplitude and phase between the two sets of data and the order of the vertical and horizontal tail bending modes was found to have changed. This is likely to be due to significant structural non-linearity as well as the non-linearity arising from the elastomeric supports and the electro-hydraulic actuators. Fig. 4
Example FRFs at two different input-amplitude levels: upper plots h18Y19Z and lower plots h18Z19Z

sec.title: 3 PROCEDURE FOR APPLYING THE RECEPTANCE METHOD OF ACTIVE VIBRATION CONTROL
sec.p: The method of receptances is a frequency-domain pole-placement approach, entirely based on vibration measurements. In the case of multiple inputs and multiple outputs (MIMO), a matrix of FRF measurements is formed. For measured force inputs and displacement outputs, this takes the form of a receptance matrix, from which the method to be explained now derives its name. It is convenient here to continue referring to receptances although it should be understood that the method is perfectly general in its application and quite often there will be advantages to be had by measuring the voltage input to an amplifier that drives an actuator and the voltage output from a sensor. Rational fraction polynomials are fitted to the measurements so that by replacing 'iω ' with 's ', receptance transfer functions, H(s), are formed. There is no need to know or to evaluate the matrices, M, C, and K. Also, when the system of equations is written in terms of receptances (1) it is seen that each row is complete when all the applied forces are known. In general, there will be fewer actuators than sensors, m<n; so the matrix of receptances is non-square. Conventional methods, such as state-space, require systems of equations cast in terms of dynamic stiffnesses (2) in which it is necessary to have a sensor at every oneof the n coordinates of the system. It is for this reason that conventional methods require observers (or equivalent) for the estimation of unmeasured state variables. Thus, with the receptance method there is no requirement for an observer andmodel reduction is not necessary since the resulting matrices are generally of small dimensions.

The Sherman–Morrison formula [5] may be used to obtain closed-loop characteristic equations in the form [1] (3) where s=μk is a closed-loop pole to be assigned, (g f) the acceleration and velocity gains, and b the actuator distribution vector (for single-input control). equation (3) is linear in the unknown gains, so that forthe assignment of k pairs of closed-loop poles, the following system may be assembled (4) (5) where (6)

The dimension of G is (2k×2n). It will be a square matrix when the number of pairs of poles to be assigned is equal to the number of sensors (assumingthat displacement is obtained by integrating a velocity measurement), over-determined when the number of pole pairs exceeds the number of sensors, and underdetermined when there are more sensors than the number of pole pairs to be assigned. It is often desirable to distribute the control force by having several actuators at different points on the structure, but the assignment of poles is not dependent upon the dimension of the b vector – in theory, all the poles of the system can be assigned using asingle actuator. It was shown by Ram and Mottershead [1] that the matrix G is invertible whenthe system is controllable and that (g f) are real when the closed-loop poles are assigned in complex-conjugate pairs.

The procedure may be shown to be equivalent to the well-known state-space approach to pole placement except the system matrix, usually denoted by (sI-A), is replaced by H(s). The relationship between the inverse system matrix (in the form of WJ Duncan) and the matrix H(s) was given, for example, by Mottershead et al. [10].

sec.title: 4 OPEN-LOOP TESTS
sec.p: The open-loop tests were carried out with a zero-mean random input voltage in the range ± 2 V as described previously. The output voltages from theaccelerometers and their integrals (related to velocities) were the feedback signals. Integration was carried out in the dSPACE environment and these signals were filtered using a band-pass Butterworth filter with cut-off frequencies 8 and 40 Hz.

In the frequency range of interest, 12–30 Hz, modal tests had shown the cabin structure to be relatively rigid, whereas the nose and certainly the tail were more flexible. Therefore, accelerometer signals were measured at nodes 1 (nose), 2, 3, 10, and 11 (cabin floor), and 14, 15, and 18 (tail) in the y- and z-directions. In what follows, two pairs of closed-loop poles are assigned, in which case dim(G)=4×32, which is clearly very underdetermined. Pseudo-inversion of this matrix, which leads to the minimum norm solution, works perfectly in simulation but fails to do so in practice. Of course, the minimum norm solution leads to small values of the gains (g f) having virtually no effect on the system, which remains almost unchanged from the open-loop condition because the control signal is in the range of the input noise. In order to overcome this problem, the number of sensors was reduced to three: accelerometers at nodes 1, 15, and 18 in the y- or z-directions separately.

Curve fitting to measured FRFs may be done using MIMO or SISO (single input and single output) routines. In the case of a multi-degree of freedom system with multiple sensors and actuators, the application of MIMO curve fitting is strictly required to ensure the system natural frequencies are the same at every measurement point. However, it is known that in practice the use of SISO curve fitting often results ina smaller fitting residual. Thus, MIMO and SISO curve fittings were used in turn. Examples of MIMO curve fits are shown in Fig. 5 where the full (blue) lines are the measured values and the curve-fitted data areshown in dashed (red) lines. Fig. 5
Measured and curve-fitted FRFs: (a) h15Y,19Z, (b) h18Y,20Z, (c) h15Z20Z, and (d) h18Z19Z

sec.title: 5 CLOSED-LOOP TESTS
sec.p: Pole placement was achieved by negative feedback ofacceleration and velocity. Measured acceleration signals were integrated and filtered to obtain the velocity. The control gains (g f) were implemented using dSPACE controller hardware and the resulting control forces in real time were added to the random excitation to drive the two actuators.

sec.title: 5.1 Pole placement at μ1,2=-1±84i,μ3,4=-2±160i,and b=(1 1)T
sec.p: In this case, three accelerometers 1, 15, and 18 were used in the y-direction and the control forces at the two actuators were operating in phase. The poles were deliberately assigned with small real parts so that the damping would be small and peaks would show up clearly on the closed-loop FRF measurements. There are two simulated closed-loop results obtained by applying Sherman–Morrison formula. The first, denoted by the dot-dashed (green) line, uses synthesized FRFs obtained by MIMO curve fitting to the open-loop measurement. The second, denoted by the dashed (red) line, uses the measured open-loop FRFs directly. It is seen that there is very little difference between the two sets of results in the frequency range of interest. Peaks at approximately 84 and 160 rad/s show that the desired pole assignment has been achieved. Fig. 6

Real-time implementation in dSPACE was carried out using gains (g f) determined using two different curve-fitting methods, MIMO and SISO. The open-loop transfer function in Fig. 7 is represented by the full (blue) line and the two closed-loop measurements are denoted by the dashed (red) and dot-dashed (green) lines for SISO and MIMO curve fits, respectively. It can be seen that the two closed-loop tests are very similar. Details of the closed-loop FRFs close to the assigned poles are given in Fig. 8. The closed-loop FRFs appear to be noisier than the open-loop ones because fewer averages were taken in their computation. Fig. 7
Experimental results for pole placement at μ1,2=-1±84i and μ3,4=-2±160i Fig. 8
Zoom showing details of closed-loop FRF peaks for the first case: (a) first-assigned pole pair and (b) second-assigned pole pair

The locations of the open- and closed-loop poles on the complex s-plane, determined by curve fitting, are marked in Fig. 9. Some of the open- and closed-loop poles are spurious and arise only as a result of the curve-fitting procedure. The closed-loop poles are not exactly assigned but are very close to the prescribed values. There are many possible reasons why the poles are not assigned exactly, but probably one of the most significant reasons is the known non-linear behaviour of the structure, explained previously. The actuators, located between the roof of the fuselage and the raft, were not ideally placed to control modes in the tail. Consequently, large control forces were required, though the input voltage was limited to ± 10 V(significantly greater than the random input at ± 2 V). The use of several actuators distributed across the structure would enable the modes of the airframe to be controlled at lower cost (lower control force) and with less non-linear effect. The numerical values of the real parts are much smaller than the imaginary parts of the closed-loop poles,so that the percentage error in the real parts is likely to be greater than the percentage error in the imaginary parts, caused originally by the pseudo-inverse of G. Fig. 9
Location of the open- and closed-loop poles

It can be seen by comparing the open- and closed-loop mode shapes in Figs 3 and 10 that the two assigned modes, originally 12.6 Hz (5.3 per cent damping) and 25.4 Hz (5.93 per cent damping), have been reassigned to 13.7 Hz (0.98 per cent damping) and 25.2 Hz (1.28 per cent damping), close to the desired values. The closed-loop mode shape at 13.7 Hz appears to be a combination of the two open-loop modes at 12.6 and 14.6 Hz. Clearly, the damping values have been much reduced, as required. The airframe vertical bending mode originally at 17.5 Hz was not assigned but has shifted. In principle, it is possible to control this mode as well as the other two, but this is impractical because of the large control forces necessary, at the limit of the capability of the present actuators. The actuator locations were determined for a different purpose, the AgustaWestland ACSR system as explained previously, and are not ideal for the present feedback control experiments. The distribution of several actuators at different locations across the airframe would allow the assignment of more modes at less cost (lower control force). Alternatively, partial pole placement [4] may be applied where actuators are deliberately placed to make certain poles uncontrollable while others are assigned – the uncontrollable poles remain unchanged from their open-loop values. Of course, partial pole placement is not an option with the present actuator configuration. It is seen from Fig.8 that the closed-loop system remained stable. Fig. 10
Closed-loop mode shapes: (a) tail bending, vertical + horizontal, 13.7 Hz (86 rad/s), 0.98% damping; (b) vertical bending of airframe, 17.0 Hz (107 rad/s), 2.18% damping; (c) horizontal bending of airframe, 25.2 Hz (157 rad/s), 1.28% damping

sec.title: 6 CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: The receptance method was applied for active vibration control by pole placement of the AgustaWestland W30 helicopter airframe. The method, based on the measured input–output transfer function, in this case, made use of the input voltage to the amplifier of the actuator and the measured acceleration signal. Single-input state feedback was used in a series of experiments to assign two poles of the helicopter to predetermined values. A sample of simulated results was provided and experimental closed-loop FRFs were shown to agree with the simulated values. The plots of the location of the open-loop and closed-loop poles in the complex plane by curve fitting to the measured FRFs were used to confirm that the assignment had been achieved successfully. The study was carried out in a very limited time frame, but was enough to show that the receptance method has considerable practical merit. It was decided in these experiments to use active control to deliberately reduce the damping of certain modes, so that the peaks would be very clear on the closed-loop measured FRFs. Of course, a more practical experiment (were time available) would be to increase the damping of the modes or possibly to shift the frequencies by a greater amount, though shifting frequencies is generally more difficult than increasing (or reducing) damping. The poles were not assigned exactly, possibly because large control forces were needed and the structure was shown to be non-linear. The actuators placed between the roof of the fuselage and the raft were not ideally located to assign modes in the tail and it is therefore considered that the poles could be shifted further at less cost if a number of actuators were placed to optimize the controllability of the modes to be assigned. The distribution of actuators at different locations across the structure would enable a greater number of pole pairs to be assigned and partial pole placement to be achieved so that selected pole pairs are assigned while others remain unchanged from their open-loop values.
